G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease and tenancy agreement in Massachusetts and is expressly protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the landlord of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239 and is responsible for providing essential services, including hot water, in compliance with Massachusetts law and the applicable State Sanitary Code.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the landlord of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239 and is responsible for providing essential services, including hot water, in compliance with Massachusetts law and the applicable State Sanitary Code.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action between landlord and tenant arising from the rental of residential premises located in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is a civil action between landlord and tenant arising from the rental of residential premises located in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the Premises are located in Brockton, Plymouth County, and the events and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: As part of the rental agreement, and by operation of law, Defendant was and is obligated to provide and maintain the Premises in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including the obligation to provide adequate and compliant hot water to the dwelling.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease and tenancy agreement in Massachusetts and is expressly protected by G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment, states that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right,” and ties that common-law covenant to G.L. c. 186, § 14’s statutory protection for interference with quiet enjoyment. The court thus both recognizes the implied covenant in all tenancies (including residential) and treats § 14 as the statute that expressly protects that right, matching the proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.” (citing G. L. c. 186, § 14).

105 C.M.R. 410.190, 410.190(A).proposition: The provision of hot water is an essential service required by law for residential premises in Massachusetts. See 105 C.M.R. 410.190, 410.190(A) (requiring landlords to provide and maintain adequate facilities for hot water at prescribed minimum temperatures).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every tenancy in Massachusetts. Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states, as part of its discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law background, that every tenancy carries an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. That is precisely the legal proposition cited: that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every tenancy in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. Id.” (citing Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977)).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every tenancy in Massachusetts. Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and how a landlord’s acts or omissions can breach it, but it does not state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every tenancy in Massachusetts. The case applies and interprets the statute rather than announcing the general common-law implication rule attributed to Simon v. Solomon. Thus it does not clearly support the specific proposition that the covenant is implied in every tenancy.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “3. Covenant of quiet enjoyment. The plaintiffs argue that the judge erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the defendant on their claim that the defendant violated G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), the so-called ‘quiet enjoyment’ statute. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 94 (1982). … General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference.”}

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain essential services and sanitary conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where such failure results in a serious or substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: Blackett concerns late-night noise from a bar operated on premises leased by the landlord to another tenant, and holds that such noise, when within the landlord’s control, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. The case does not address failures to maintain essential services or sanitary conditions; instead it deals with noise and nuisance from a commercial use. Thus, while it supports the broader concept that serious interferences can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically support the proposition framed in terms of essential services and sanitary conditions.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942) (intrusions of smoke and soot over a substantial period of time due to a defective boiler).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain essential services and sanitary conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where such failure results in a serious or substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–18 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service required by the State Sanitary Code—“seriously impairs” the character and value of the premises and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Although the case is specifically about heat rather than all sanitary conditions, it clearly stands for the broader principle that failure to maintain essential services, when it causes serious interference with use, breaches quiet enjoyment. The court also emphasizes that liability turns on the effect on the tenant’s rights, not the landlord’s intent or financial ability.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 786–87 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that repeated or prolonged sanitary code violations and loss of essential services, including heat or hot water, may constitute violations of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 786–87 (1994); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 307–08 (1977).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the landlord’s failure to correct numerous sanitary, building, and fire code violations—including inadequate heat and hot water and serious vermin infestation—constituted a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that such omissions, where the landlord has notice and the conditions foreseeably and substantially impair the premises’ value as a dwelling, fall within § 14. This squarely supports the proposition that repeated/prolonged sanitary code violations and loss of essential services like heat or hot water may violate § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that repeated or prolonged sanitary code violations and loss of essential services, including heat or hot water, may constitute violations of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 786–87 (1994); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 307–08 (1977).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does involve G.L. c. 186, § 14 and a violation of quiet enjoyment, but the underlying defects are a leaky roof and defective floors, not loss of essential services such as heat or hot water. The court’s discussion focuses on how § 14 damages are calculated (actual vs. three months’ rent), not on whether repeated or prolonged sanitary code violations or loss of essential services constitute a § 14 violation. Thus, while Darmetko is relevant to § 14 remedies, it does not stand for the specific proposition about sanitary code violations and loss of heat or hot water.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: The judge further ruled that the leaks in the roof (but not the defective floors) interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. Because of this interference, and based on his reading of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the judge ruled that the plaintiff was entitled to an additional $5,358, three times her monthly rent obligation ($47) for each month during which the leaky roof was unrepaired... Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference "with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises") shall "be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater..."

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 307–08 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that repeated or prolonged sanitary code violations and loss of essential services, including heat or hot water, may constitute violations of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 786–87 (1994); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 307–08 (1977).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: McKenna v. Begin deals exclusively with damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability based on State Sanitary Code violations; it does not mention or construe G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address statutory liability for loss of essential services like heat or hot water under that statute. The opinion’s discussion of sanitary code violations is tied to the warranty-of-habitability framework, not to c. 186, § 14, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition asserted. The case is therefore mis-cited for that point of law.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt: “This case returns to us following its remand to the Superior Court for computation by the trial judge of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability. Under that warranty principle… the judge had awarded damages to the plaintiff McKenna… for violations of the State Sanitary Code… As we emphasized in our earlier opinion, not every defect gives rise to a diminution in rental value, and it has been held that isolated violations may be found not to constitute a breach of the warranty of habitability.”

The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410..raw_text: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including 105 C.M.R. 410.190
The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410..proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including 105 C.M.R. 410.190, requires landlords to supply and maintain adequate hot water facilities; a substantial and unreasonable failure to do so is a material breach of the landlord’s statutory duties and a substantial interference with the tenant’s occupancy.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–76 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is strictly liable for at least three months’ rent or actual and consequential damages, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 775–76 (1994); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 786–87.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy and, secondarily, mentions G.L. c. 186, § 14 only in passing via a citation to Simon v. Solomon. It does not analyze § 14, does not state that liability under § 14 is strict, and does not set out the statutory remedy of three months’ rent or actual and consequential damages plus fees. Accordingly, it does not provide direct authority for the specific strict-liability damages rule described in the proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Recovery by Wideman based on the contract rent does not result in an improper diversion to her of public funds. A private landlord, like Cruz Management, is not shielded from liability to which the landlord would otherwise be exposed merely because a part of its income is derived from Federal subsidy funds. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 110 n.13 (1982) (permitting recovery of treble damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, calculated on contract rent, where tenant’s rent was subsidized).

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff also relies by analogy on related landlord‑tenant authorities recognizing tenants’ rights to habitable premises and to statutory damages for serious interference with their tenancy, including G.L. c. 239, § 8A; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and interaction with quiet enjoyment); and Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486, 493–96 (2016) (discussing landlord’s statutory and common‑law duties toward tenants in residential housing).

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff also relies by analogy on related landlord‑tenant authorities recognizing tenants’ rights to habitable premises and to statutory damages for serious interference with their tenancy, including G.L. c. 239, § 8A; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and interaction with quiet enjoyment); and Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486, 493–96 (2016) (discussing landlord’s statutory and common‑law duties toward tenants in residential housing).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Hemingway as recognizing an implied warranty of habitability and its interaction with quiet enjoyment, in the context of tenants’ rights to habitable premises and statutory damages. This excerpt is a concurring/dissenting opinion, not the majority, but it accurately reflects that the case reconsiders the old no‑warranty rule and adopts a modern, code‑based habitability framework with mutual interdependence of rent and habitability obligations, in tandem with G.L. c. 239, § 8A and related statutes. The passage thus provides at least analogous support for tenants’ rights to habitable premises and remedies tied to serious interference with their tenancy, though it does not itself discuss “statutory damages” expressly.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The second step required for the removal of the roadblock is the reversal of the present common law rule that the obligation of the tenant to pay rent and the obligation, if any, of the landlord to repair or maintain the rented premises are independent, and the substitution therefor of a new rule that such obligations are substantially mutually interdependent. The opinion of the court accomplishes this… tenants shall enjoy the rights which these various legal provisions have created for their benefit.”

Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486.raw_text: Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486, 493–96 (2016)
Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff also relies by analogy on related landlord‑tenant authorities recognizing tenants’ rights to habitable premises and to statutory damages for serious interference with their tenancy, including G.L. c. 239, § 8A; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and interaction with quiet enjoyment); and Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486, 493–96 (2016) (discussing landlord’s statutory and common‑law duties toward tenants in residential housing).
Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal case (a murder and aggravated rape prosecution) focused on cell-site location information, search of a defendant’s cellphone, and a juror note. It does not discuss landlord–tenant law, residential habitability, quiet enjoyment, or any statutory or common‑law duties of a landlord toward tenants. The citation to Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486 (2016) here is therefore inaccurate for the stated landlord‑tenant proposition, which appears to refer to a different case of the same name or to different pages/opinions not included in the excerpt.
Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 474 Mass. 486.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the defendant that the search of his cellular telephone was not supported by probable cause, and that the search warrant was overly broad. As a general matter, “probable cause requires a substantial basis ... for concluding that the items sought are related to the criminal activity under investigation, and that they reasonably may be expected to be located in the place to be searched at the time the search warrant issues.” Commonwealth v. Dorelas, 473 Mass. 496, 501 (2016).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Statutory interest on all money damages awarded, from the date of filing of this Complaint or other dates as provided by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
